subNodes.conversationText: A third time we meet!--But this time I, at least, am not surprised.
[Ianth looks positively aghast. She tries to say something but cannot.]
Marcellus, you snake!  What did you have to do with Anselm's murder?
I was present, but Belforet did the honors.
[A gratified murmur escapes from Belforet, perhaps the first sound you have ever heard Marcellus's warlock companion make.]
[Marcellus regards Ianth coldy but says nothing.]
These emotional confrontations between the two of you make me most uncomfortable.
I am a mercenary.  I have always been a mercenary, even when I served your father.  When I served a good man, I was good.  Now I serve those that have different ideas of good.
No idea of good has ever admitted the murder of an innocent priest.  Even if he had confused religious opinions, he was still an innocent.
I don't presume to question the motives of my employers so far as they give me what I need.

I am a mercenary. I have never pretended to be anything else. She loved me without reciprocation; when I left her father's service, she left his house and chased me. Nothing happened between us. She was mad with love, with folly. This dream of hers--who I was to her--it wasn't real.
No, I can see that well enough myself.
What was I thinking? How could I have--? [Ianth shudders.] Was money all that it took to make you a Banite?
Fine.  What do you want from us?
It's not what I want. It's what they want. [Marcellus points behind you.]
[You recognize Brother Anselm's traitorous acolyte, the one who fled before you killed Obern.] We meet again. You've done much since we last met--associating with Harpers, now, I hear?
[To Marcellus.] I thought you had been hired by the Bane-worshipers! These men follow Cyric.
I am most upset that you haven't yet taken the point. I am a mercenary.

It did not take much calculation to conclude that the hold of the Banites in this region was loose and my tenure with them insecure.  I knew that the Cyricists would pay well for the capture of your companion, and I knew just how to get your attention.
It is an unexpected benefit that you are all newly associated with the hated Harpers.
By Sune, has it come down to this?  Must I slay you?
<color=red>[Intimidate/Bluff/Diplomacy] Wait!  I have something to say.</color>
[Success] Nothing you can say will change your fate.  The only one of you who will survive this little fray is Vroman--and he will only live so long as his brother does.  Words are useless.
Wait, Dunne.  I would hear what <FirstName> has to say.  There is nothing in my contract prohibiting a parley.

<color=blue>[Diplomacy]  Indeed.  You have served your purpose well.  You have brought us here, to the Cyricists.  We need not fight.  If you feel you owe anything to Ianth, to your old employers, to your own dignity--you will walk away from this.</color>
[Success] [Marcellus looks unsure of himself and takes a step back. He wavers, looks at his companions.]
Do not look to me for encouragement. I was not the one who suggested this job.
[Suddenly, like an actor remembering his lines, Marcellus bows to Ianth, speaking with a tinge of irony--] Lady Lavillus, I take my leave of you.
[Failure] [After what seems like a second of hesitation, Marcellus speaks.] Bah. This talks nonsense. Belforet, Teurneia--at them!
<color=red>[Intimidate]  You know what we are capable of.  Back down.  Retreat.  We will win this battle whether you stay or go, but if you go now, you go with your lives.</color>
[Success] [Marcellus looks unsure of himself and takes a step back. He wavers, looks at his companions.]

[Bluff] Knowing our ties with the Harpers, do you really think we would walk knowingly into your little trap with no precautions? You may--doubtfully--survive this battle, but you will not survive the night in these woods. Even now Harper agents scout the perimeter of Northdark, the road to Drawn Swords, and the Sunset Trail.
[Success] [Marcellus looks unsure of himself and takes a step back. He wavers, looks at his companions.]
I wished only to say that you do not deserve to live one more second, Marcellus.
[Failure] Nothing you can say will change your fate.  The only one of you who will survive this little fray is Vroman--and he will only live so long as his brother does.  Words are useless.
They are not cowards, it seems.  Well, then, they are fools.
It is an unexpected benefit that your leader now calls <him/her>self a Harper.
[A vaguely familiar-looking man stands at the head of a small band of Cyricists.]
Dunne, Brother Anselm's apprentice.  Hamfast's conjecture was right.
We meet again.  You've done much since we last met--associating with Harpers, now, I hear?
Why did the Banites want you to kill Anselm?  Was it because of his flirtation with the Cult of the Risen Sun?
Ah yes, the Banites. Those were my old employers. [Suddenly, you hear the clinking of arms behind you.]
You were my father's friend--You cared for him when he was ill--when the others left, we sat by his side together.  I was only a girl, and you--
What are you doing here, Marcellus?
[Ianth, her voice choked, blurts out--] Marcellus! How could you?! You murdered him?!
If you killed Anselm, prepare to pay in kind.
